summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting a two-week extension (to November 23, 2020) for producing electronic discovery from devices seized from Jeffrey Epstein. The delay is attributed to an outside vendor's technical processing. The letter details the defense's conditional consent and the government's partial agreement, while also outlining the extensive process of data extraction and review from Epstein's residences.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced (20 Cr. 330). The government is requesting an extension for discovery production related to her case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Electronic devices were seized from his residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands in 2019. The discovery in question originates from these devices.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her requesting an extension.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The government attorney who respectfully submitted and signed the letter to the court.

connections.description: The document references the case against Maxwell, with discovery stemming from devices seized from Epstein, indicating their alleged association in the underlying criminal conduct.

events.title: FBI searches Epstein's New York residence
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted multiple searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residence in New York and seized dozens of electronic devices.

events.title: FBI searches Epstein's Virgin Islands residence
events.description: The FBI searched Jeffrey Epstein's residence in the U.S. Virgin Islands and seized dozens of electronic devices.

events.title: Court issues expanded search warrant
events.description: The Government obtained a new warrant expanding the scope of the search of 62 electronic devices seized from Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Original discovery production deadline
events.description: The original court-ordered deadline for the government to produce discovery to the defense in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Requested discovery production deadline
events.description: The government's requested new deadline for producing the final set of electronic discovery from Epstein's devices.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY
keyFacts: The FBI seized dozens of electronic devices from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York (July 2019) and the U.S. Virgin Islands (August 2019).
Approximately 1.2 million documents from Epstein's devices were identified as responsive to search warrants and required production.
The defense's conditional consent to the discovery delay included requests for a witness list and Jencks Act material, which the government refused as having no legal basis connected to the delay.

The government had already produced over 350,000 pages of discovery and planned a sixth production by the original deadline, with the delayed seventh production being the final batch from Epstein's devices.
None of the electronic devices in the delayed production are believed to have belonged to the defendant, Ghislaine Maxwell.
